newsitem.title: USA: Goshawk pair terrorizes Anchorage joggers.
newsitem.headline: Goshawk pair terrorizes Anchorage joggers.

text.p: State biologists are advising some Anchorage joggers to alter their route, now that a pair of protective goshawks have built a nest and hatched some goslings near a popular midtown trail.

Alaska Department of Fish and Game biologist Rick Sinnott, himself a victim of the swooping birds, said at least four people have been pecked or slashed by the goshawks nesting by the Anchorage Pacific University campus trail.
The mother goshawk is the most vicious, Sinnott said Thursday. "If she sees you and you're within that 100 yards or so of the nest, she's going to get you," he said.
Sinnott said he believes several other people have been attacked, but have not yet reported their mishaps to the state.

As he was walking toward the area Wednesday, with a television news team in tow, another pair of joggers ventured too close to the nest, he said. "One was screaming, so I suspect it got him, too," the biologist said.

Northern goshawks are common in Anchorage, but it is rare for the birds to set up nests so close to buildings and well-used trails, he said. "They're all around town, but they don't normally cause so much trouble," he said.
Sinnott has posted signs warning trail users of the peril. "Caution!!! Aggressive goshawk in vicinity," the signs say.
The birds on the campus trail should settle down in a few weeks, when their hatchlings grow large enough to fly on their own, Sinnott said.
